attributes.claim: In the Poetics, for example, Aristotle invokes Sophocles when he instructs dramatists to “elaborate the plot by language (kai tē lexei sunapergazesthai) and by keeping the material before the eyes (pro ommatōn tithemenon) as much as possible” (1987, 17.l.1.1455a).2 Yet the idea of words as visual apparatus is by no means limited to the ancient stage.3 Indeed, this communicative synesthesia marks one of several cru- cial places where Aristotle’s Poetics overlaps with his Rhetoric, producing both arts as wordy arts that tap into bodily and visual faculties.4 A few his- torians of rhetoric, including Aristotle’s main rhetorical translator, George Kennedy, have begun to notice in the Rhetoric such visual-rhetorical con- cepts as phantasia, bringing-before-the-eyes, and energeia or activity.5 It is my aim to augment their efforts by drawing together these and other concepts in order to form a dynamic theory of what might be called rhetor- Downloaded by [The UC Irvine Libraries] at 17:42 08 February 2016 ical vision.

attributes.claim: Since of these principles numbers are by nature the first, and in numbers they seemed to see many resemblances to the things that exist and come into being—more than in fire and earth and water (such and such a modification of numbers being justice, another being soul and reason, another being opportunity—and similarly almost all other things being numerically 30 expressible); since, again, they saw that the attributes and the ratios of the musical scales were expressible in numbers; since, then, all other things seemed in their whole nature to be modelled after numbers, and numbers seemed to be the first things in the whole of nature, they supposed the elements of numbers to be the 986'i elements of all things, and the whole heaven to be a musical scale and a number.
